bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 4, 1900

div1.p: Reed makes plans for the Fourth of July, and he describes Cuban flowers.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 4, 1900
div1.opener:
Camp Columbia,
July 4, 1900
No. 13-
Wednesday-
5:30 am.
why don't you sleepy children wake up & enjoy
the beautiful morning?
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
My precious wifie:
div1.p:
I guess you
have made great preparation
for a 4th of July Celebra-
tion at Keewaydin- I can see
you touching off the giant-
crackers and clapping your
hands with glee, as the deaf-
ening roar fills your ears
and resounds over the hills!
Great sport that! Reveille
is just sounding and over the
ravine I hear the strains of
“Columbia the gem of the ocean”-
by the 7th Cavalry- By the way
there are two good military bands
here, 7th Cav. & 8th Inf -- and as
I write I can hear the 8th Inf.
Band playing, also, but this
time it is “Yankee Doodle”-
Borne to me on the breeze at
this early hour of the morning, you
don't know how very pretty it
sounds- Lawrence told me that
his regiment was making great
preparations for celebrating
the fourth, by foot races, games
of ball & c. As for me, I think
that I shall remain quietly
at home, and, this afternoon,
take a nice drive on the
Guanahay road in the new
wagon that Gen. Wood has
kindly placed at our Board's
disposition- This will enable
us to drive into Havana
whenever we please without
waiting for the rail-road,
I haven't told you anything about
the flowers here, at this season.
Only two or three are seen
blooming- The Hibiscus & the
Flamboyant or (I think) Royal
Ponciana- The latter is exqui-
site beyond description- The
tree grows something of an um-
brella shape & its whole crown
is one flaming mass of
scarlet- The leaves which
are of a beautiful shade
& borne on plumes, come
just after the flowers begin
to bloom! you can't imagine
anything more beautiful or
more striking seen at a dis-
tance- There are hundreds of them
dotting the landscape- The Hi-
biscus is always blooming-
immense red flowers -- occas-
ionally seen as a hedge ex-
tending 50 yards or more --
yesterday was a little warmer
than it has been, but last
night was delightful and I slept
like a great big top- The Post-
man tells me that from July 1st, Ha-
vana will have 3 mails a week
& not five as heretofore- It will
arrive Mondays, Wednesdays & Sat-
urdays & leave the same days so
that I will now expect not less
than 2 letters from my sweet babies
every time the mail arrives! Hesche!
“Habla Español”? Boo! Boo! you
sweet joys- Be good children and
write very often & tell me everything.
Love & kisses for my darling children.
